qas.question: What was the formalization of the division of small powers and great powers?
During the post Napoleonic era where were the first Great Powers concentrated?
During what 2 wars was the balance of power shift most dramatic?

answers.text: World War I and World War II

qas.question: What is another term for Great Power?

plausible_answers.text: to represent the most important powers in Europe during the post-Napoleonic era

qas.question: Why was the term formalization and division first used?
Which international balance of power formally created the division between small and great powers?
In what year was the definitive list of powers signed?

plausible_answers.text: World War I and World War II

qas.question: For which post Napoleonic era has the balance of power shifted dramatically?
What is another term used in place of international balance of power?

context: The term "great power" was first used <b4_0>to represent the most important powers in Europe during the post-Napoleonic era<b4_0/>. The "Great Powers" constituted the "Concert of <a1_0>Europe<a1_0/>" and claimed the right to joint enforcement of the postwar treaties. The formalization of the division between small powers and great powers came about with the signing of the <a0_0><b5_0>Treaty of Chaumont<b5_0/><a0_0/> in <b6_0>1814<b6_0/>. Since then, the international balance of power has shifted numerous times, most dramatically during <a2_0><b7_0>World War I and World War II<b7_0/><a2_0/>. While some nations are widely considered to be great powers, there is no definitive list of them. In literature, alternative terms for great power are often world power or major power, but these terms can also be interchangeable with <a3_0><b8_0>superpower<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
